ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
LOCAL MEDIA
(Review of rules)


    1. Mr Ong Ah Heng asked the Minister for Information and the Arts whether the Government is going to review the rules on the local media in order to pave way for greater competition in the industry, and, if so, whether the Government is prepared to give licences to news groups,

Column: 2282

apart from Singapore Press Holdings, to publish newspapers which may be partially or wholly owned by foreign companies.

    The Minister for Information and the Arts (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government is currently studying the local media structure to keep it abreast of market and technological changes. Whilst it is useful to have market competition, the control of the domestic media should remain in local hands because of their unique nation-building role. They can help unify and share local highpoints and viewpoints among Singaporeans, and get the Government's official position through to the people. Foreigners must not be able to use media to influence local politics.

    Our present rules, such as the 3% cap on ownership by any one person and the requirement that only Singaporeans may own management shares, are thus still relevant because they ensure that these goals are met.

    Mr Ong Ah Heng (Nee Soon Central): Sir, advertisers always feel that it is expensive to advertise in the newspapers. Could the Ministry control the prices of advertisements in the newspapers so as to make it more affordable?

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, we believe in a free market here, whether it is for advertisements or for other things. I think we should leave it to market forces. If the newspapers are too expensive, the advertisers can resort to other media. For example, we get a lot of junk mail in our post boxes. There are also the TV and other media that they can use.

    Mr Ong Ah Heng: Sir, as far as the media is concerned, there is no free market. It is a monopoly. Therefore, I ask whether the Ministry can control the prices of advertisements.

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, there is no monopoly. There are so many newspapers, although they are under the SPH umbrella. But they all compete like cats and dogs.

    Question again proposed.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, I am very glad that this Government has set up Community Development Councils (CDCs) to more effectively cater to the needs of the people. I am concerned about the direction the CDCs should go in order to be relevant and perceived as relevant to our citizens. I would like to suggest that the CDCs should be proactive in areas that affect a majority of residents and on programmes that benefit more residents in the constituencies. Ideally, the CDC can be a form of "local government".

    I would like to suggest that the CDC also venture into three areas that I am familiar with; areas where most families will benefit from and can appreciate from long-term outcome. These areas are:

    (1) Healthcare is generally an important issue to most people and, frequently, it is a political one too. Singapore is no exception. It is, hence, an area worthy of the CDCs' attention.

    A programme that can benefit all the households of our residents and also something that will improve the health of all the residents would hold the CDCs in good stead. I am suggesting that the CDCs sponsor everyone above 50 years of age for health screening tests on a regular basis. The Minister for Health announced yesterday on the launching of a community health screening programme. The CDCs could perhaps co-sponsor this scheme for residents on the amount payable

Column: 2284

by them, especially those less well off residents.

    Sir, this has the benefit of making sure that preventive care is extended to everyone, especially to the poorer and less informed. This will ensure that Singaporeans will have better health and happier lives. It will thus help in containing the cost of healthcare in the future as well as in enhancing the economic contributions of a healthier citizenry. The tangible benefit for a lot of households, as many households have at least one person above 50 years, will be good for our nation too. The CDCs are the best to carry out this programme because it has the machinery of the grassroots workers to ensure comprehensive coverage of residents in the constituencies. The Ministry of Health shall lend the medical resources and the follow-up of patients that require them.

    (2) Sir, the second area that I would like CDCs to consider is the complete take over of MediFund and the future ElderCare Fund. CDCs should be the decision-making body in the disbursement of these Funds because, as "local councils", they will know the residents' needs better. The grassroots also have better rapport with the residents in assessing the eligibility of the applicants. This is better than letting social workers of the hospitals to do the job. Members of Parliament can be the advisors and perhaps hand out the awards to the residents.

    (3) Sir, as we are facing a fast-increasing aging population in Singapore, I would like to urge CDCs to redouble its attention in these potential problems that come with it. The CDCs should consider setting up and subsidising Centres of Activity for Retired and Elderly (CARE) island-wide. These centres are to make sure that the increasing numbers of elderly have places to go to every day where they can have beneficial physical, mental and social care. The purpose is to maintain them to be as healthy and active for as long as possible. The elderly who attend these centres will appreciate the effects and their children will have peace of mind knowing that they are catered for while they are there.

    Sir, I hope the Minister for Community Development would consider my suggestions.

    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh (Nominated Member): Sir I would like to speak on two points. One is on the identity and role of CDCs.

    I have followed with great interest the development of CDCs since its launch in 1997. Since then, the CDCs have committed 500 over projects, found jobs for many residents and served almost like a "local government" for 300,000 people.

    I strongly welcome the strategic move to take over some of the responsibilities so far carried out by MCD. I have long argued for the need to work small, stay targeted and relevant to smaller population bases, which have different demographic characteristics and distinct socio-economic needs. The Mayors and the MPs in each ward would know best what the people want, how they wish their environment to be organised and whom they can mobilise to kick-start community projects. There is no better way to create a sense of ownership and responsibility among residents.

    In so far as the CDC defines itself as a bridge between the people and the public sector, it must then see itself as a capacity-building agency within the people sector, and not as a Government instrument designed for exerting more control over the community. Is CDC prepared to accept the active, egalitarian participation of citizens who are free to debate, contest and challenge issues that affect them? Or is it prepared to only encourage individuals and groups to rise from the grassroots to undertake self-help projects already defined by the CDC management? The distinction community leaders made between the role of an activist within a civil society movement and that of an agent in creating a civic society will impact in numerous fashions the way we organise projects, communicate and share responsibility. Undoubtedly, it is going to be a very complex decoupling and re-emerging process where the promises of civil society and that of civic society can

Column: 2286

somewhat be negotiated. It will take time, and it takes a lot of trust.

    The experiences on the ground so far have yielded a mixed satisfaction level and mixed successes. Although the perceptions have improved since 1997, a thorny issue persists, among others, in the relational aspects of cooperation between the older grassroots leaders and younger professional social service operators, between the CDC management and the community agencies. The groups are divided by age, social class, experiences, differences in skills, attitudes and interests. If these differences are not managed, people's agencies will just shut themselves out.

    It is difficult enough to accept CDCs as non-Government, because they are led by politicians, but it can be less "bureaucratic" or jeng-hu or "government", so to speak, by adopting flexible, open, fair and accountable inter-personal skills to interact with a more demanding, questioning citizenry, one which seeks more information and is not likely to merely follow instructions.

    Sir, I propose that the National Community Leadership Training Institute (NCLTI) take the lead in organising workshops for the grassroots organisations within each CDC. It would be useful to include key partners in other sectors as well, like the Police, social service agencies, polyclinics, residents' committees and so on. We would need very good facilitators to get this going. I believe that when people work and learn together, the greater are the chances of building rapport with one another and making sense of the meaning of "community". An even more concrete suggestion is to regularise an on-going workgroup for people to meet and discuss community concerns and solutions. Such regular face-to-face interactions are more effective in generating the social capital that encourages civic engagement.

    CDCs can serve as strong bridges, but without effective networkers, they cannot become effective community builders. Without professionalising the personnel by equipping them with a range of skills in building

Column: 2287

community, the goals of S21 which CDCs are tasked to execute at the community level will be harder to realise.

    I hope this weekend's gathering on the 19th for the nine CDC leaders will identify the kind of leadership attributes needed for CDCs. The clarion call made by Mr Eddie Teo could serve as a lead for more discussions. His call was to ask the civil servants to open up, share information, be responsible to constructive ideas and tolerant of differences. This same message must be adopted by the voluntary sector as well as by community leaders and social workers.

    My second point is about making CDCs a "virtual neighbourhood". We could kick off a pilot project by CDCs sponsoring old computers for a limited number of participating households in one constituency. We can request the help of polytechnic students to design an easy-to-use Internet training programme to promote Internet literacy. It is my wish to see simple computers and even simpler programmes that older persons could learn to use to create this virtual neighbourhood.

    Eventually, an on-line service connected to the CDC will serve as the coordinating centre to answer all queries, respond to assistance calls and make the necessary referrals. This is where volunteers and students could be mobilised to manage this on-line service.

    In London, at Islington, where such a networking experiment was tried, participants were able to exchange information as mundane as gardening tips, recommend a plumber or electrician, find a baby-sitter or exchange notes on shops and restaurants. These bits and pieces of everyday life created the vibrancy of a shared and a caring community and allowed more communication among residents which could not have happened otherwise. The company, Microsoft Corp, which sponsored this experiment called this their first "cyberstreet community

Column: 2288

project". Maybe this is something CDCs could spearhead to help make Singaporeans, young and old, Internet literate and connected. I believe technology must be made simple and broadly applied to promote some level of social cohesion.

    Mr Ang Mong Seng (Bukit Gombak)(In Mandarin): Recently, the results of a survey conducted by the National Youth Council revealed that out of the 100 youths surveyed, only one was interested in social work, while 55% of them were more interested in outdoor activities and public entertainment. Such surveys have aroused my interest. The Ministry of Community Development has also conducted a survey on some 25,000 grassroots leaders. According to the survey, 60% of the grassroots leaders were over the age of 60, and 25% between the ages of 30 and 40. These two surveys showed that our young people are disinterested in social work. Such survey results merit our attention. It is a problem that we will have to solve.

    Singapore is a multi-racial and multi-cultural society. The fact that we are able to enjoy peace and racial harmony is due to the fact that all of us work towards the same goal to build a better home for Singapore. The important factor for such an achievement is that we have very strong grassroots organisations. They help to build our social cohesiveness. They act as a bridge between the Government and the people. They convey messages from the Government and also receive feedback from the people. Such hardworking grassroots leaders merit our admiration. I know certain grassroots leaders have been working in the constituencies for long periods of time. They sacrificed their time and donated their money. They worked very hard for the society. Many grassroots leaders worked for more than 30 years and have devoted their life to society. Such dedication is exemplary. Our young people should emulate them. Most of these people are quite elderly and when they leave the scene, we would have no young people to take over from them. We have to do something about this. We have to work out some plans to encourage our young people to be involved in community work.

    The Chairman: Mr Jeyaretnam is not here. Mr Harun Ghani.

    Mr Harun Bin A. Ghani (Hong Kah)(In Malay): The Muslim residents in the Jurong area are grateful to the Government because, for many years, the Government has allowed Muslims to use the land in Jurong to build a mosque, which is the Jalan Majapahit Mosque. Unfortunately, at the end of 1999, the Mosque could not function any more because the site has been acquired. Therefore, the Muslim residents in Jurong, Jurong West, Gaik Poh, Nanyang, Old Jurong Road, Boon Lay and the workers in the Tuas industrial area and its surroundings also do not now have a place to go and observe congregational prayers and attend religious classes. So the residents there are appealing to the Government, through the Minister in charge of Muslim Affairs, for a mosque to be built in the Jurong West area because there are now 65,000 residential units in the area. According to the Development Guide Plan, each area with 20,000 units of residential units ought to have one place of worship for each religion. I believe that with this density of population in Jurong, it is timely for Jurong West to have a mosque.

    The Chairman: Mr Sin Boon Ann is not speaking. Mdm Claire Chiang.

    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh: Sir, we have about 12,400 people with disabilities who are currently receiving services from the VWOs. One main concern that this group faces is that of employment opportunity. It is within our national interests that we build an environment for persons with disabilities to optimally function as independents. For me, employment is the key pillar in empowerment.

    We have a centralised employment centre, Bizlink that provides vocational assessment, placement, training, counselling/follow up for disabled people. In 1996, only 272 placements were made, but since then, the employment situation became increasingly difficult for the disabled community due to the economic crisis.

    Our Government does not enforce employment legislation for the disabled.

Column: 2290

However, various incentives are provided to encourage organisations to hire people with disability. Allow me to raise two promotional schemes because I feel they have not been publicised enough. First, the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore permits employers to claim a tax deduction of up to $100,000 when they modify their business and premises to help their disabled workers. Second, the Singapore Chinese Chamber Foundation reimburses the salaries of each disabled worker employed by the private sector for the first one and the half months. It provides a transport and meal allowance of $5 a day for the first two weeks of employment, channelling the money through the Ministry of Community Development.

    Sir, could we ask the Government to be generous and complement the role of the Chinese Chamber by matching the reimbursement amount to the disabled community and the companies that employ them on the basis of co-sharing principle? This initiative may well succeed in incentivising companies to offer jobs and individuals with disability to seek jobs.

    Sir, let me turn to the employment issue. Could Bizlink serve as a labour contractor responsible for placing groups of workers in a work context and be responsible for ferrying them to and from work and helping them adjust to the work environment? The advantage of placing more than one worker is self-evident. The disabled person feels supported. Or could the role of contracting employment for the disabled in groups be left to individual organisations so that they can find the appropriate employment placement for those under their charge? Because they would know what their clients could do and tasked with this job they will find the work contracts that are suitable to the work and skills levels of their clients and they could conduct orientation and support programmes at work to give employers their fair return and help workers feel useful.

    In Japan, the Labour Department actually adopts an integration model by

Column: 2291

setting a quota of 1.8% of employment of persons with disabilities for companies with more than 300 regular employees. If such companies failed to comply, a levy of 50,000 yen is imposed on the companies. On the other hand, employers who recruit more, above the quota, will be paid a grant of 25,000 yen per person per month for the number of disabled persons employed in excess of the quota. This is a very enlightened labour policy, as it encourages companies to open up more jobs for people who are disabled.

    Sir, the Japanese integration and rehabilitation model has a lot to teach us. Not only is their disabled community being encouraged to function in the open market, large ventures are encouraged to contract them to be part of the production teams. One example is the operation of big printing presses. The persons with disabilities do the less physical demanding jobs of desktop publishing, mailing, and so on, while the able workers do the physically more demanding ones. This way the workshop can provide the full range of service to the customers from desktop publishing to printing and mailing service, like in any commercial printing company. Through training and close supervision, out of work and during work, the flourishing of commercial ventures in Japan involving persons with disabilities has proven one vital point: that the disabled are not unable and they are economically productive if they are given a chance and adequate support. We need employers to open up more jobs with some levels of incentives from Government. We need MOM to provide an employment bulletin for jobs posted by employers who are really willing to recruit the disabled. We need to strengthen the assessment and referral procedures of Bizlink and other VWOs.

    The Chairman: Dr Jennifer Lee is not speaking. Dr Lily Neo.

    Dr Lily Neo: Sir, I have repeatedly raised in this House, over the past three years, various issues about the aged in our country. Notwithstanding the embarrassment of being a bore to my colleagues, I

Column: 2292

seek their indulgence on this topic one more time. Please allow me to reiterate an important issue concerning ageing of the population. I refer to the financing of healthcare for senior citizens in the future. I am raising this issue under the Ministry of Community Development because it is the lead agency to implement the recommendations of the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Ageing Population.

    As I have mentioned in this House before, there is an inadequacy in our present healthcare financing in spite of our Medisave, MediShield and Medifund schemes. This was recognised by the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Ageing Population and is referred to as "Expanding Step-down Care Financing". It is recommended that the Ministry of Health and the Central Provident Fund Board establish, as I have advocated in this House as well, an insurance scheme against severe disabilities. It is also recommended that the premiums be made less burdensome by making it payable with Medisave. Sir, my main contention on this issue is that we must make sure this insurance scheme addresses the problem well and its execution is well planned, lest we find it still lacking after implementation.

    In order to ensure success, this insurance scheme must cater for all aspects of "step-down care" and contrary to the recommendations of the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Ageing Population, must include medical expenses. Yes, coverage of medical expenses is an important part of "step-down care" and must be included. Many "step-down care" patients need continued medical care and long term medications after their discharge from the hospitals. If the medical expenses are exclusive of the "step-down care" and are excluded from financing, this financing scheme will only fail. Sir, our future cases of chronic-disease sufferers will heavily burden our tertiary medical institutions, raising the healthcare costs unnecessarily when they can be cared for in the community facilities or in their own homes. But they will opt not to because they can only use Medisave

Column: 2293

and MediShield in the tertiary institutions and not at community facilities or when they stay at home. I hope that we do not let this serious mistake take place, or we will have a perpetual flaw in our system.

    I hope the Minister for Community Development can steer the implementation of this issue with favourable outcome.

    Dr Ho Tat Kin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, with good medical care, senior citizens are now living to an older age, averaging about 77 years. Currently, there are already cases where the old, about 60, are looking after the yet older parents who are in the 80s. This type of elderly care is obviously not efficient. Although the full impact of the ageing population will not be seen until 15 to 20 years' time, I am glad that the Government had taken the initiative with a high-level Inter-Ministerial Committee to make an in-depth study on this issue. While the Inter-Ministerial report on the aged is a total approach to the issue, I believe the Ministry of Community Development and Sports should be the lead Ministry to take care of the total solution. Based on the current budget allocation, this amount will not be sufficient to take care of the ageing population. The Ministry should work closely with the Ministry of Finance for higher budget allocation which could be related to the population of the aged.
1.00 pm

    Sir, currently, young mothers are allowed to take leave to take care of sick children below the age of six. With the ageing population, I would like to ask for elderly parent care leave which will allow workers similarly to take care of aged parents of 60 years and above. This will encourage more people to take an active part in the care of ageing parents.

    The fertility rate has dropped from 1.82 in 1980 to 1.48 in 1999. If this trend continues, there will not be enough siblings to take care of their parents. Loneliness will be the biggest problem which the aged will have to learn to cope with. Teaching the senior citizens how to cope

Column: 2294

with ageing will be a major task. The Ministry should work out comprehensive plans to help senior citizens adjust to the problem of ageing, especially in the mindset. Preparing for retirement with sufficient money is only one important aspect. There are many other variables to take care in ageing.

    Sir, the Ministry has over the years spawned a whole new industry in childcare centres. These childcare centres provide good care for children with working parents. The Ministry should now draw up guidelines and provide good incentives for the private sector and VWOs to set up more senior citizens care centres, where workers could place their elderly parents, and professionally trained geriatric care staff can take good care of senior citizens at affordable rates.

    Mr Ang Mong Seng(In Mandarin): Sir, at the moment, there are about 280,000 people aged 60 and above. By the year 2030, there will be about 400,000 such people. Later on, there may be about one million such senior citizens in Singapore. So we must have a comprehensive plan to tackle the problems of an ageing population.

    I have three suggestions to make. On the family, Minister Mah Bow Tan has mentioned that there are about 800,000 families in Singapore, and the number is likely to rise to one million. On the average, there will be one senior citizen in every family. So, at home, we have to start to educate our young to respect the old and take care of them. We must also ensure that there is good care for the old people. As it is said in Chinese, "Look after your own old people and extend it to look after other people's old people too." We must be caring to all the old people around us, so that we have a compassionate and caring society.

    We spent a lot of time talking about setting up more childcare centres because of the need for them. In view of the ageing population, we must also seriously think about establishing more elderly-care centres.

    I think the MCDS should consider setting up day care centres for the elderly

Column: 2295

at our community clubs or community centres. Now that the trend in our society is to have small families, couples have to work in the day time, while the old people are left at home. They may feel very lonely. So if you have day care centres in the community centres and the community clubs, then such senior citizens can go to the centres to read newspapers, watch TV, sing karaoke songs, or do some physical exercises. These day care activities will certainly make life happier and more wholesome for such old people.

    As it is said, the four essential things in life are: clothing, food, housing, and transportation. To our old people, clothing is not much of a problem. As for housing, the Ministry of National Development has already announced various measures to make the HDB flats more user-friendly for the elderly, such as having lift landing on every level, etc. Minister Mah Bow Tan has already actively considered this issue.

    Another suggestion is that we must have regular health screening for senior citizens. Minister Lim Hng Kiang has already accepted my proposal. I would like to thank the Minister for this.

    The third one is transportation problem. I mentioned this in the debate on the President's Address. Generally, we have a good and safe public transport system in Singapore. We have taxis, buses, MRT and LRT, and so on. But although the senior citizens are granted concessions for the use of public transport, these concessions are restricted to certain periods of the time. I would like to ask if this time restriction can be removed. I understand that the Inter-Ministerial Committee has accepted this proposal in principle. Now it is for SBS and TIBS to implement this recommendation. Hitherto, I have not heard any good news on it.

    There are two approaches to tackle this problem. One is when you want to do something, you take the proactive approach and actively look for ways and means to achieve what you have targeted to achieve, so that your plans may be

Column: 2296

carried out smoothly. Recent events in Kosovo, India, Nigeria and, closer home, in Indonesia, show how deep-rooted the feelings of race and religion are. We must never take each other for granted, even if we can. We must continue to build on the respect and understanding we have for each other. With more time and effort, our bonding will strengthen even further. We must never relax this important aspect in the education of our young.

    Sir, I come now to the last issue of my cut. Some people have advocated that more money should be spent to educate our good students so that they can be even better. We need capable people to lead. This makes sense. Others have advocated that more money should be spent to help those who are less able. They need more help to level up. This also makes sense. On the latter line of argument, many parents therefore have suggested that more and better resources be deployed at the primary school level. If

Column: 2352

primary students have a good and strong foundation, they will need less help in the future years. The allocation of resources for education is thus perplexing. Just how has the Ministry of Education been allocating its resources? Many would like to know how the money budgeted to the Ministry of Education is allocated to the schools. The neighbourhood schools in my area and both elsewhere in Singapore could make do with more help to become even better schools.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, over the last few years, there have been several significant changes in our education system. We have moved from an emphasis on rote learning towards greater creative thinking, away from an academic orientation towards a wider scope of methods through which students can express themselves and be assessed. Curriculum has been reduced in favour of that objective and we also have improved infrastructure and facilities. And perhaps, most important of all, we also have developed IT teaching in schools and used it as a vehicle for creative expression. All these are very important changes in keeping with the times and they prepare us for the so-called new economy.

    But, Sir, a certain bias appears to have crept into our vernacular. We appear to talk of the old economy in somewhat disparaging terms and the new economy in somewhat glowing terms. If I may illustrate. In this House, we have numerous references on the need to work at Internet speed, the need to embrace the new economy, otherwise we risk being left behind. The suggestion is also that if we do not do so, then we might be somewhat remiss in the task of governance. In the media, we find front page coverage to young junior college students who have become entrepreneurs or technopreneurs, as the new vernacular will suggest, taking risks and being prepared to fail and wear failure as a badge of honour. We also have less than complimentary references in the media to the old world economy veterans, like Warren Buffet that he has not embraced the new changes with as much speed as he should have.

Column: 2353



    Sir, these are important messages in their own right. But they should be kept in their context. Ultimately, the Internet and the new economy is just another way to create wealth. It does not represent a new paradigm for the way we organise ourselves, or the way we govern ourselves, or the way we relate to each other. And I think this is the point that must be communicated effectively to our students, through national education, and other measures, that we must be fast but not hasty in decision making, particularly when it comes to policy that affects millions of Singaporeans; that we must be connected but not confuse connectivity with being involved with everything, everywhere, all the time; that we must be informed, especially when making important decisions, but that we should not be overwhelmed by this information that is available out there, to be able to sieve out what is important and what is not.

    Sir, ultimately, the so-called Internet speed has its limits, particularly in terms of in what context it can be applied.     Sir, I think national education is the key to maintaining that balance in our education system and I would urge the Minister to pay particular attention to how this balance is brought about in the message we give our young so that they do not get so enamoured of the wild wild west of the Internet that they forget the old home with its yellow brick road.

    Mr Davinder Singh (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, my question is how is our education system being reviewed to keep it in step with what is needed in the new economy? We have had a great deal of discussion both in and outside the House about how we should anticipate and meet the challenges of the knowledge-based economy.

    We have identified two goals, and I speak rather apologetically after Mr

Column: 2354

Iswaran has spoken. First, to transform our universities into what has been described as "incubators for inspiration". Second, to develop a pool of entrepreneurs willing to take risks and a large group of workers with a thirst for knowledge and a high degree of creativity.

    These are highly commendable objectives. They signal a determination to transform our economic culture from one which breeds conformity of thought and embraces prudence to one which celebrates intellectual dissonance and aims to remove the stigma of failure.

    We are on the right track. There is no question that the system will, in a few years, throw up more entrepreneurs and innovators that we now have. But that is not the point. The real issue is whether we will churn out a few more or many more. The answer, in my view, depends largely on our education system. I do not contend that the education system should be tweaked to teach entrepreneurship. I subscribe to the view that a person is either born with the stomach and inclination to go off the beaten track or he is not.

    Therefore, in my view, the true question is not whether the education system can nurture entrepreneurs. It is whether it can avoid dampening, or worse, extinguishing the potential of the few who have it in them to make a difference.

    We have to be realistic. We do not have the numbers which the United States or China or India enjoy. They have a far larger pool of school children. It stands to reason that their odds of producing thinkers and innovators are much shorter than us.

    We cannot seriously compete on numbers. So we have to concentrate on quality. The question is: does our education system preserve or lengthen our odds in this game?

    Let us examine our education system. It imposes standards and norms, whether of behaviour or achievement. This is not a criticism. It is a fact. From young, children are taught that there are prescribed methods of finding solutions.

Column: 2355



    You are made to believe that your test and examination results reflect your ability and potential. That has served the country well. But are we hurting our chances in the new world? I was not surprised when I read that the report by the National Youth Council suggested that many young Singaporeans feel that scoring "As" is enough to ensure them a bright future. Can you take these same people, who for 12 years have been told that they should play by long established rules and that grades are everything, and suddenly transform them into hungry and curious participants of the new economy?

    Today's Straits Times carried a report that parents of pre-schoolers believe that discipline is more important than creativity. 80% of parents who were interviewed felt that pre-schoolers should have worksheets. This is not surprising. Singaporeans are very practical people. They have become system smart.

    It is going to be a mammoth task to change the mindset of administrators, principals, teachers, parents who have so skilfully adapted themselves to the system and are very comfortable with the existing norms. Unless we make the effort and overcome the resistance, we will continue to have scores of school leavers who will see no sensible reason to stick their necks out or go against the flow.

    Many of you will remember an athlete by the name of Richard Fosbury. Until 1968, for those who follow athletics, high jumpers moved from first to the fourth gear and then up they went over the bar. In 1968, Dick Fosbury came along and he did the unthinkable. He moved from first to third gear, and just before the bar, turned direction, engaged reverse gear, and soared over it. He won the gold medal but that is not as important as the fact that he changed the game.
4.15 pm

    What are the chances of our system preserving the spark of a local Dick Fosbury? Consider this. In Mathematics,

Column: 2356

our children are taught that getting the right answer is not enough. The method must be right or marks will be deducted. He is taught that he has to stay in his lane. I am sure there is a good reason for that, but do you think that we are shortening or lengthening our odds?

    We must move away from prescription and regurgitation in the schools. Children should be assessed not only on content, but also on the ability to think on their feet and around problems. The answer does not lie in giving them more projects. The sooner we realise it, the better because most of them will end up being done by the parents.

    It is not going to be easy to develop a pool of entrepreneurs and a creative workforce. We need to find ways to preserve the potential of the very small numbers that we have. It will be a terrible waste if the education system continues to transform the street-smart into the system-smart.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Sir, we all appreciate the need to have clearly defined desired outcomes of education so that we will not stray from equipping our scarce human resources with the necessary skills for sustaining both our economy and society. Many an argument has been made to allocate more time to deserving needs, such as national education, inculcation of values, sex education and the list goes on.

    I would now like to urge the Minister to seriously consider including technology as a compulsory subject, at least from the secondary school onwards. This is not just to make them entrepreneurs or Net savvy. This is because technology literacy now ranks as high as language literacy. Without a working knowledge of technology or specifically of computers and the Internet, we will be handicapped. The world is now a little smaller if we go by traditional means of acquiring knowledge, such as reading hard copies of newspapers and periodicals, books from the library and news over television. If we explore all that is at our disposal via the Internet, we get the opposite effect, that is,

Column: 2357

information overload, too many sources, too many channels and too many possibilities. But obviously, to operate and survive in a global economy, we cannot afford to limit our ability to do more and know more.

    Hence, we should aim at ensuring that our students understand the Internet and related technology enough to navigate and choose. With technology literacy, they have a tool which they can exploit to maximise their own potential. Having computer-based education in schools is not quite the same nor good enough. Even if certain skills were picked up, such as logging on and logging off and the differences between the different disk drives, the emphasis is still very much on the content rather than the technology itself.

    I am asking for schools to incorporate the equipping of such skills in a timely fashion as curriculum proper and not be left as co- or extra-curricular activities, such as leaving IT club to teach web design.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)(In Mandarin): Sir, in this budget, the Ministry of Education made out a long list of achievements in its educational ideals. However, from two recent incidents, I

Column: 2358

cannot help but ask myself what are the educational results that we have attained.

On the other hand, the vast majority of Malay and Indian students wished to remain as Malays and Indians respectively in their next life.

How is it that there is a great difference in their basic sense of belonging for their ethnic groups?     However, all the ethnic groups in Singapore are subjected to the same western culture and the same globalisation. How is it that the survey reveals that the inclination of the Chinese students is so different from that of the students from the other ethnic groups?

This has affected the Chinese community most. Apart from the language and the family traditions, there is no effective method under the Government's policy to nourish their sense of belonging to their own ethnic group. Unlike in the Malay community, when the Malays go to the mosque and attend the various activities connected therewith, their sense of belonging to their own ethnic group is strengthened, and the use of their language enhanced. On the other hand, apart from the Government's Speak Mandarin Campaign and some related activities, there is nothing very much in our social framework to make the ethnic Chinese in Singapore enhance their sense of belonging to their community.

Column: 2359



    Now with the education system turning to use English as the main medium of instruction, learning of English literature made compulsory in the secondary schools, and some schools offering European history rather than Asian history, many Chinese students have very limited knowledge of their own history and their own literature. No wonder they do not have a sense of belonging to their own racial group. I do not know whether the aims of our education system is such that we want to blur the students' sense of belonging for their own ethnic group in order to enhance their sense of belonging to Singapore as a nation.

    The second incident was this report on 2nd March in the Straits Times that one top student from a neighbourhood school was originally from a well-known school. However, during his younger days, he committed a number of offences and had criminal convictions. As a result, many schools did not want to take him. Fortunately, this neighbourhood school admitted him and gave him a second chance. He seized the opportunity, turned over a new leaf, and scored many 'As' in his 'O' level examinations. While we are talking about a holistic approach to attain our educational ideals, some schools are using this unilateral policy. Some schools want to attain high ranking, and they are only concerned with students scoring good results for them to attain their target. To them, it is better that those students who do not behave well do not come as they may ruin the reputation of the school. If the mindset of the school administrators is such that they are so eager for quick results and instant benefits, then how can we expect them to educate our students in a holistic educational approach in order to attain the desired outcomes of our education policy?

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, our drive to develop a nation of entrepreneurs with the required creativity to invent and innovate and to inculcate the concept of life-long learning further reinforces the need for us to re-look at our current system of education which served the

Column: 2360

purposes of the nation in the past and, which in my opinion, requires changes in a number of areas if we are really serious about achieving these goals of developing every Singaporean to his or her full potential.

    I believe that one of the key considerations of the education system that we have in place today is to achieve efficiency in the delivery of education and hence, we have been doing things like streaming, teacher postings, assessment, measurement of school performances and other like things. While from the point of view of the system and those managing the system, this looks very good and the outcomes of which are easily measurable, the negative impact is that we develop a nation of people who fit into just one model of success.

At least some of them will make it. We need to ensure that our people will always be able to adapt to changes by constantly learning new skills, and it is time that we took a serious look at how we should modify our education system. Because the impact of the education system will only be felt 10 to 15 years from the time it starts, in my opinion, the issue has also become an urgent one.

    My question to the Minister is whether we are looking at the right models of education from around the world and to adapt the best practices to suit Singapore. In my opinion, our system basically trains our children for one-career model of life, very much like the traditional Chinese and Japanese systems which placed scholars among the top rung of society. As BG George Yeo recently put it in one of his speeches, such a system actually prevented the Chinese from exploiting the benefits of trade and new technology and, therefore, they are losing out in this competition to western countries. In my opinion, we really need to look at some

Column: 2361

western models in order to achieve the new outcomes of our education system.

    Sir, without doubt, the Americans were the leaders for innovation, technology and economic development in the past century, better than any other nations around the world. Similarly, they will have an excellent chance to remain the leaders in this century. I therefore feel that it is about time we learned from the Americans and other western models of education, not to copy them wholesale, but to pick the best practices among them and develop our own model for Singapore. I really feel that we can learn a lot from their systems, which may not be the most efficient in the world, but do produce the results. So, what good does it do to score the highest marks in the Science and Mathematics competitions around the world when the desired outcomes of an education system cannot be achieved? So I suggest that we be prepared to give up some amount of efficiency in our system to achieve the end results for the country.

    I also feel that we should re-look at the practice of early streaming of our children. This has been my pet topic for some time. The system basically divides our children into categories and put the people of the same capabilities in the same place and segregate people of differing talents. This is once again good for efficiency, but bad in that it does not allow our children to benefit from learning from people of differing talents. I strongly believe in the strength of diversity that if they can learn from people of different talents or different abilities, they probably would turn out to be better students or adults in the future. Our children are missing out on the important opportunity to learn from others.

    Sir, all of us in this House, including the Minister, came through an education system that mixed people of differing abilities together for many years of our school system. I am sure that you must agree with me that the outcome has not been a bad one, where all of us have been able to compete effectively with the world's best countries. I would like to ask the Minister

Column: 2362

whether there is any other education system in the world that practises streaming in the way that we do here in Singapore.

    Sir, if we are serious about the concept of life-long learning, then our current methods of measuring success and failure need to drastically change. It is more important to ensure that a student has learned the ability to learn in the future than to learn to score well in examinations and in doing so, achieving academic excellence which we very much want our children to achieve today. Learning to score well in examinations is not going to inculcate the value of life-long learning, so we really need to develop other measures of success in our education system. Similarly, the measures of creativity and EQ deserve more emphasis as we move ahead and ECA, project work and life experiences should feature strongly in our new measures of success. To be successful in the 21st century, we need to develop a more adaptable society, able to pick up new capabilities and skills all the time, and not just once in their lifetime.
4.30 pm

    Finally, Sir, I am curious to know how the concept of mass customisation of our education system is working. The Minister announced this some time last year. The question I have is: is it really possible to implement the system? Perhaps the Minister can share with Members of this House how this system can be practically implemented.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua: Sir, I would like to follow up on my colleague, Mr Inderjit Singh's theme to explore further afield for best practices in education. With the numerous developments on the education front as well as the fast-changing economy that we are trying to cater to, I would like to discuss the role of the private sector in education.

    Currently, the private sector plays an active role in both the pre-school and university segments. There is a wide variety of choices on both fronts and within the desirable framework; families

Column: 2363

can decide the type of services they want for the children. However, the private sector, by and large, does not participate in the provision of primary, secondary and pre-university education for Singaporeans.     Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Sir, I am going to start by begging your forbearance, because I am about to bring up two old subjects and, being new in the House, I have the advantage of not having heard the debates before. I will try however not to be too lengthy about it.

    Sir, the single biggest stresser for Singaporean families is worry over their children's education. The Ministry of Education has, in recent years, introduced many admirable new initiatives. These include measures which address factors that contribute to the pressure on students, such as curriculum review with a view to decrease curriculum load and the review of university admission criteria to de-emphasise reliance on 'O' and 'A' level results.

    When you talk to senior officers in MOE, they are enthused, convinced and sincere about these good efforts. When we talk to parents and teachers on the ground, however, we might be excused if we were to think that they were living in a different world. The pressure continues unabated. Why this incongruence? Because for all the good intentions and sincere efforts, certain fundamental issues have not been resolved.

    Parents are anxious for their children on two counts. Firstly, they worry about their children being able to access tertiary

Column: 2364

education and hence, subsequently, earn a good living. Secondly, they worry about their children being labelled from an early age as slow, stigmatised, socialised differently in the system and written off as no- hopers. As the changes to the admission criteria start making their impact to the system, the first pressure point should ease. However, this takes time to happen. But the anxiety with regard to the early labelling of children will persist so long as we continue with our policy of streaming children as young as at primary four. The second pressure point remains as real as ever.

    In the meantime, curriculum review notwithstanding, so long as ranking of schools remains, principals will continue to strive to push their schools up the academic ladder and apply pressure on teachers who will, in turn, continue to push their students. Even the additional refinement of measuring schools with most value added for their students, they still measure this value added in academic performance. No amount of exhortations that it is not necessary to push students to complete 110% of the curriculum by the first quarter of the year, so that the next two quarters can be spent on revision and drills, and no amount of assurances that other achievements also count, will have any effect so long as the Ministry continues to rank schools on their academic results.

    Principals and teachers will continue to be convinced that their assessment, progress and promotions are tied to the academic results of their pupils and institutions. The pressure will not let up. I am not at all denying or dismissing all the benefits and advantages of ranking and streaming. There were obviously good reasons why they were introduced in the first place. But as in any policies, there are always two sides to the balance. It is a matter of which side of the balance sits heavier. And as time progresses, sometimes the balance shifts. For ranking, on one side is the ability to benchmark and assess the schools, and provide parents with information on how the schools rate. On the other side is the unhealthy competition that this engenders, and the

Column: 2365

resulting pressures that go right through the system. The question is truly: what would we lose if we were to drop the system of ranking schools?

    For streaming, on one side is the purported ability to identify children who would otherwise not be able to cope, to help them with the less demanding load. On the other side is the labelling of the children at an early age with all the attendant consequences, to their self-esteem, the loss of opportunities open to other children not so labelled, and the loss to the system of late developers, and the loss of the diversity, which Mr Inderjit Singh has just referred to. The question is truly: is there no other way to help along slower children but to segregate them in this manner?

    I know the Minister has received many calls in the past to review the policies of ranking and streaming, but I will venture to ask him to do so again. I believe it is time, the balance has tipped, because the pressures are weighing very heavily on the other side. I am sure that many Members of the Frontbench would also agree if only they were not constrained by the solidarity required of their positions.

    Sir, my plea to the Minister is to please pause, throw out previous pre-conceptions and premises, and review these two policies. Before I end, Sir, I would also like to take the opportunity to invite the press to make their contribution towards easing off on this undue adulation of academic results. We have just missed an opportunity as this year's 'O' and 'A' results have just been released. But from next year, I suggest to them to propose a blackout on coverage of the top students in the PSLE, 'O' and 'A' level examinations. All they are going to disappoint are a few proud parents, but it would be their contribution in the cause of promoting a saner society less preoccupied with the paper chase.

young with skills for the knowledge-based economy. IT skills are tools that should help our students learn better and develop the ability to apply what they have learnt. year. That the schools were able to do so in a clean sweep point to the tremendous amount of planning and effort that have gone behind the scene.

position. Nevertheless, his case highlighted the unique primary one allocation scheme in Singapore. costs in order to make the school look good. With this mindset still prevailing, can the Minister tell us how can we ensure that the education of our students be more open and creative, learn how to think instead of how to memorise in order to remain relevant in this fast changing world?
